snippet: An argument in a subway train turned to blows, and one man pulled a gun and killed another. The police and prosecutors are still considering whether the killing constituted a crime.
abstract: Police and prosecutors in New York City are struggling with how to classify death of Gilbert Drogheo, who was fatally shot by retired correction officer William J Groomes during subway altercation; district attorney's office is still weighing whether use of force was justified; police charge Drogeho's friend Joscelyn Evering with assault and menacing in same incident.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Nate Schweber and John Surico, and research by Susan C. Beachy.

lead_paragraph: An argument in a subway train turned to blows, and one man pulled a gun and killed another. The police and prosecutors are still considering whether the killing constituted a crime.

headline.main: Focus in Brooklyn Subway Shooting Is on Whether Deadly Force Was Justified
headline.print_headline: Focus in Subway Shooting Is on Whether Deadly Force Was Justified
